message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The non-blanching, raised erythematous papules on the legs suggest leukocytoclastic vasculitis, which can be associated with abdominal pain and joint swelling. The positive stool test and recent use of antibiotics may suggest an underlying infection such as streptococcal infection, but acute rheumatic fever is less likely given the absence of other major criteria. Immune thrombocytopenic purpura and familial Mediterranean fever are less likely given the absence of other characteristic symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The non-blanching, raised erythematous papules, and positive stool occult blood test suggests Leukocytoclastic vasculitis, which is often associated with an underlying systemic disease. The sore throat and treatment with amoxicillin suggest a possible infection leading to the vasculitis. The other options would have different presentations and laboratory findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The non-blanching raised erythematous papules on the legs and positive stool for occult blood suggest Leukocytoclastic vasculitis as the most likely diagnosis. Acute rheumatic fever would have presented earlier with sore throat, and Familial Mediterranean fever would have presented with recurrent fevers, abdominal pain, and joint pain. Immune thrombocytopenic purpura can cause purpura but not the other symptoms present in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The non-blanching raised erythematous papules on the legs suggest leukocytoclastic vasculitis. The positive stool test indicates gastrointestinal involvement which is common in this condition. Acute rheumatic fever can cause joint pain but it’s more commonly seen in older children and adolescents, and there is no rash. Immune thrombocytopenic purpura usually presents with a sudden onset of bleeding, whereas this patient has no bleeding symptoms. Familial Mediterranean fever is a genetic disorder that usually presents with recurrent fevers and abdominal pain.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The non-blanching, raised erythematous papules and limited range of motion in the ankle joints suggests Leukocytoclastic vasculitis. The positive test for occult blood in the stool suggests gastrointestinal involvement. Immune thrombocytopenic purpura and Acute rheumatic fever do not typically present with these symptoms. Familial Mediterranean fever is a genetic disorder characterized by recurrent fevers and inflammation in the abdominal cavity, chest, and joints, but does not involve skin or joint symptoms like those described in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The non-blanching, raised erythematous papules, swollen and warm ankle joints, limited range of motion, and positive stool test suggest Leukocytoclastic vasculitis. Immune thrombocytopenic purpura also presents with a decreased platelet count, but there is no evidence of bleeding. Acute rheumatic fever presents with joint pain but does not usually have a rash. Familial Mediterranean fever presents with attacks of fever, peritonitis, pleuritis, and joint pain but not skin manifestations.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The non-blanching, raised erythematous papules suggest leukocytoclastic vasculitis, which is often associated with abdominal pain, joint pain, and gastrointestinal symptoms. The positive stool occult blood test suggests gastrointestinal involvement. Immune thrombocytopenic purpura is characterized by a low platelet count and does not typically present with joint pain or gastrointestinal symptoms. Acute rheumatic fever is a possible diagnosis as a result of the sore throat, but it is not associated with a positive stool occult blood test. Familial Mediterranean fever typically presents with recurrent episodes of fever, abdominal pain, and joint pain, but does not typically present with a rash or swelling of the ankles.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of abdominal pain, rash, and joint swelling suggest Leukocytoclastic vasculitis. The positive stool for occult blood may indicate gastrointestinal involvement. Immune thrombocytopenic purpura would have a lower platelet count. Acute rheumatic fever would have symptoms related to the heart, such as chest pain and shortness of breath. Familial Mediterranean fever would have a lower age of onset and recurrent episodes of fever and abdominal pain.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The non-blanching, raised erythematous papules on the lower extremities, along with abdominal pain and positive stool occult blood test, suggest Leukocytoclastic vasculitis. Acute rheumatic fever may also have joint pain but usually follows a streptococcal infection of the throat, not treated with amoxicillin. Immune thrombocytopenic purpura may have a low platelet count but will not present with the other symptoms described. Familial Mediterranean fever is less likely given the specific symptoms and presentation described.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The nonblanching, raised erythematous papules and positive stool test suggest leukocytoclastic vasculitis, which is an inflammation of blood vessels. The abdominal pain and ankle swelling are also common symptoms of this condition. Immune thrombocytopenic purpura is a bleeding disorder that usually presents with petechiae and ecchymoses, but not with joint swelling. Acute rheumatic fever usually follows a streptococcal pharyngitis and presents with fever, migratory polyarthritis, and carditis. Familial Mediterranean fever can cause abdominal pain and fever, but not joint swelling or rash.
